saberes: A. Communication
- Self-confidence. Errors as an instrument for improvement.
- Basic strategies for the comprehension, planning and production of brief, simple and contextualized oral, written and multimodal texts.

- Knowledge, skills and attitudes that allow initiation in mediation activities in basic everyday situations. Basic communicative functions appropriate to the field and context: greeting and introducing oneself, saying goodbye, introducing someone, thanks, invitations; describing people, animals, objects, places and habits; placing events in time and narrating past and recent events; placing objects, people and places in space; requesting and exchanging information about everyday matters and daily actions and their frequency; describing routines; giving directions and instructions; expressing the belonging and quantity; expressing ability, taste, preference, opinion, agreement or disagreement, feeling, intention; making requests and offers of help, giving information and asking for permission, suggesting plans and reporting plans, go shopping or go to a restaurant, talk about experiences.

- Contextual models and basic discursive genres in the comprehension, production and co-production of oral, written and multimodal, brief and simple, literary and non-literary texts: characteristics and recognition of the context, organization and structuring according to the internal structure.

- Basic linguistic units and meanings associated with such units such as expression of the entity and its properties, quantity and number, space and spatial relations, time, affirmation, negation, interrogation and exclamation, elementary logical relations .

- Basic vocabulary of interest to students, related to personal identification, close interpersonal relationships, nearby places and environments (home, city, town), leisure, free time and sports, daily life and family and friends; work and occupations; travel, vacations and transportation; health and healthy living habits; education and study; shopping and commercial activities; food, healthy habits and recipes; languages and communication; environment and sustainability and climate; wonders of the world, information technologies and communication; cinema and television, lexicon related to festivities in English-speaking countries and lexicon linked to the reading plan of the subject.
- Basic sound, accentual, rhythmic and intonation patterns, and general communicative functions associated with these patterns.

- Basic orthographic conventions and meanings associated with formats and graphic elements. Basic conversational conventions and strategies, in synchronous or asynchronous format, to start, maintain and end communication, take and give the floor, ask for and give clarifications and explanations, compare and contrast, collaborate, etc.
- Resources for learning and strategies for the guided search for information in analog and digital media.
- Intellectual property of the sources consulted and contents used.

- Basic analogue and digital tools in common use for oral, written and multimodal comprehension, production and co-production; and virtual platforms for educational interaction and collaboration (virtual classrooms, videoconferences, collaborative digital tools...) for learning, communication and the development of projects with speakers or students of the Foreign Language.
B. Multilingualism

- Strategies and techniques to compensate for communication deficiencies to respond effectively to a specific need, despite the limitations derived from the level of competence in the foreign language and in the family languages.

- Basic strategies of common use to identify, organize, retain, recover and use linguistic units (lexicon, morphosyntax, sound patterns, etc.) from the comparison of the languages and varieties that make up the personal linguistic repertoire.
- Strategies and basic tools of common use for self-evaluation and co-evaluation, analogical and digital, individual and cooperative.
- Lexicon and commonly used expressions to understand statements about communication, language, learning and communication and learning tools (metalanguage).
- Elementary comparison between languages from elements of the foreign language and other languages: origin and relationships.
C. Interculturality
- Basic strategies of common use to understand and appreciate linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity, taking into account ecosocial and democratic values.
criteriosEvaluacion: 1.1. Recognize, interpret and analyze the global meaning, as well as specific words and phrases of short and simple oral, written and multimodal texts on frequent and everyday topics of personal relevance and areas close to their experience, as well as literary texts appropriate to the level of development of the students, expressed in a comprehensible, clear way and in standard language through different supports.

1.2. Select, organize and apply in a guided way appropriate strategies and knowledge in daily communicative situations and relevant for students to capture the global meaning and process explicit information in various texts.

2.1. Express orally short and simple texts, previously prepared, about everyday matters and relevant to the students, using verbal and non-verbal resources in a guided way, and using basic and frequently used forms and structures typical of the foreign language.

2.2. Organize and write Produce short and simple texts, previously prepared, appropriate to the proposed communicative situation, through analog and digital tools, and using commonly used structures and basic vocabulary on daily and frequent matters, of personal relevance to the student. students and close to their experience.

2.3. Select, organize and apply knowledge and strategies in a guided way to prepare and produce texts appropriate to the communicative intentions, the contextual characteristics and the textual typology, using, with help, physical or digital resources depending on the task and the needs of every moment.

3.1. Plan and participate in brief and simple interactive situations on everyday topics, of personal relevance and close to their experience, through various supports, relying on resources such as repetition, leisurely rhythm or non-verbal language, and showing empathy and respect for linguistic courtesy and digital etiquette, as well as for the different needs, ideas and motivations of the interlocutors.

3.2. Select, organize and use, in a guided way and in everyday situations, elementary strategies to greet, say goodbye and introduce oneself; ask and answer simple questions; express messages, and start and end communication.

4.1. Infer and explain texts, concepts and brief and simple communications, in a guided way, in situations in which attention is paid to diversity, showing respect and empathy for the interlocutors and for the languages used, and interest in participating in the solution of intercomprehension and understanding problems in their immediate environment, relying on various resources and supports.

4.2. Select and apply, in a guided way, basic strategies that help create bridges and facilitate the understanding and production of information and communication, appropriate to the communicative intentions, using, with help, resources and physical or digital supports depending on the needs of each moment.
5.1. Compare and contrast the similarities and differences between different languages, reflecting in a progressively autonomous way on basic aspects of how they work.

5.2. Use and differentiate progressively autonomously the knowledge and strategies to improve their ability to communicate and learn the foreign language, with the support of other participants and analog and digital supports.

5.3. Register and use, in a guided way, the progress and difficulties of learning the foreign language, recognizing the aspects that help to improve and carrying out self-evaluation and peer-evaluation activities, such as those proposed in the European Language Portfolio (PEL) or in a learning journal.

6.1. Act with appreciation and respect in intercultural situations, building links between different languages and cultures, and showing rejection of any type of discrimination, prejudice and stereotype in daily and habitual communicative contexts.

6.2. Accept and respect the linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity typical of countries where the foreign language is spoken as a source of personal enrichment, showing interest in understanding basic cultural and linguistic elements that promote sustainability and democracy.
6.3. Select and apply, in a guided way, basic strategies to understand and appreciate linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity.
